question_text: Reduce the following equations into slope intercept form and find their slopes and the y-intercepts: (i) x + 7y = 0, (ii) 6x + 3y – 5 = 0, (iii) y = 0.
correct_answer: For (i) rewriting x + 7y = 0 gives y = −(1/7)x, so the slope is −1/7 and the y‐intercept is 0. For (ii) 6x + 3y − 5 = 0 yields 3y = −6x + 5 or y = −2x + 5/3, so the slope is −2 and the y‐intercept is 5/3. For (iii) y = 0 is already in slope intercept form, with slope 0 and y‐intercept 0.
explanation:
• (i) Starting from x + 7y = 0, subtract x to obtain 7y = −x, then divide both sides by 7: y = −(1/7)x. Here the coefficient of x (−1/7) is the slope and the constant term (0) is the y‐intercept.
• (ii) From 6x + 3y − 5 = 0, rearrange to 3y = −6x + 5 and then divide by 3 to get y = −2x + 5/3. Hence the slope is −2 and the y‐intercept is 5/3.
• (iii) The equation y = 0 has an implicit slope of 0 (horizontal line) and a y‐intercept at 0.

question_text: Reduce the following equations into intercept form and find their intercepts on the axes: (i) 3x + 2y – 12 = 0, (ii) 4x – 3y = 6, (iii) 3y + 2 = 0.
correct_answer: For (i) 3x + 2y – 12 = 0: Set y = 0 to get x-intercept, which gives 3x = 12 so x = 4; set x = 0 to find 2y = 12 so y = 6; intercept form: x/4 + y/6 = 1. For (ii) 4x – 3y = 6: x-intercept from y = 0 gives 4x = 6 so x = 3/2; y-intercept from x = 0 gives −3y = 6 so y = −2; intercept form: x/(3/2) + y/(−2) = 1. For (iii) 3y + 2 = 0 yields y = −2/3; since x does not appear, the line is horizontal with no x-intercept (except if interpreted as intercept at infinity) and the y-intercept is −2/3.
explanation:
• (i) To get the intercepts for 3x + 2y − 12 = 0, substitute y = 0 to get x = 4 (x-intercept) and x = 0 to get y = 6 (y-intercept); rewriting gives the intercept form x/4 + y/6 = 1.
• (ii) For 4x − 3y = 6, letting y = 0 gives x = 3/2 and letting x = 0 gives y = −2; therefore, the intercept form is x/(3/2) + y/(−2) = 1.
• (iii) The equation 3y + 2 = 0 leads to y = −2/3, which is a horizontal line and hence it does not cross the x-axis (or can be considered to have no finite x-intercept).

question_text: Find the distance of the point (–1, 1) from the line 12(x + 6) = 5(y – 2).
correct_answer: First, write the line in standard form. Expanding 12(x + 6) = 5(y – 2) gives 12x + 72 = 5y – 10, which rearranges to 12x – 5y + 82 = 0. The distance from point (–1, 1) is |12(–1) – 5(1) + 82|/√(12² + (–5)²) = |–12 – 5 + 82|/√(144 + 25) = 65/13 = 5.
explanation:
• Expand the given equation: 12(x + 6) becomes 12x + 72 and 5(y – 2) becomes 5y – 10. The equation is 12x + 72 = 5y – 10.
• Rearranging gives 12x – 5y + 82 = 0.
• Use the distance formula: Distance = |Ax₀ + By₀ + C|/√(A² + B²) where (x₀, y₀) = (–1, 1), A = 12, B = –5, and C = 82.
• Compute the numerator: |12(–1) – 5(1) + 82| = |–12 – 5 + 82| = |65| = 65.
• Denominator: √(12² + (–5)²) = √(144 + 25) = √169 = 13.
• Thus, distance = 65/13 = 5.
topic: Distance from a Point to a Line

question_text: Find the points on the x-axis, whose distances from the line (x/a) + (y/b) = 1 are 4 units.
correct_answer: Any point on the x-axis has the form (x, 0). Substitute y = 0 in the line to get x/a + 0 = 1, so the line meets the x-axis at (a, 0). The perpendicular distance from a general point (x, 0) to the line (x/a)+(y/b)=1 is given by |(x/a) − 1|/√(1/a² + 1/b²). Setting this equal to 4 gives |(x/a) − 1| = 4 √(1/a² + 1/b²). Multiplying by a, we have |x − a| = 4a√(1/a² + 1/b²) = (4√(a² + b²))/b. Thus, x = a ± (4√(a² + b²))/b.
explanation:
• A point on the x-axis is (x, 0). Its distance from the line in intercept form is given by the formula: Distance = |(x/a) + (0/b) − 1|/√(1/a² + 1/b²).
• Setting |(x/a) − 1|/√(1/a² + 1/b²) = 4 leads to |(x/a) − 1| = 4√(1/a² + 1/b²).
• Multiply through by a to obtain |x − a| = 4a√(1/a² + 1/b²).
• Recognize that √(1/a² + 1/b²) simplifies to √(a² + b²)/(ab). Thus, the equation becomes |x − a| = (4√(a² + b²))/b.
• Solve the absolute value equation: x − a = ± (4√(a² + b²))/b, so the two x–coordinates are x = a + (4√(a² + b²))/b and x = a − (4√(a² + b²))/b.
topic: Distance from a Point to a Line; Intercepts

question_text: Find the distance between the parallel lines (i) 15x + 8y – 34 = 0 and 15x + 8y + 31 = 0, and (ii) l(x + y) + p = 0 and l(x + y) – r = 0.
correct_answer: For (i), the distance d = |C₂ – C₁|/√(15² + 8²) = |31 − (–34)|/√(225 + 64) = 65/√289 = 65/17. For (ii), the lines are l(x + y) + p = 0 and l(x + y) – r = 0. Their distance is given by |p – (–r)|/√[l²(1² + 1²)] = |p + r|/(√2 |l|).
explanation:
• (i) For two parallel lines of the form Ax + By + C = 0, the perpendicular distance between them is |C₂ − C₁|/√(A² + B²). Here, A = 15, B = 8, C₁ = −34, and C₂ = 31. Substituting gives the distance as 65/√(225+64) = 65/17.
• (ii) For the lines l(x + y) + p = 0 and l(x + y) − r = 0, note that the normal vector is the same for both (l, l). The difference in the constant terms is |p − (−r)| = |p + r|. The length of the normal vector is |l|√(1² + 1²) = |l|√2. Thus, the distance is |p + r|/(√2 |l|).

question_text: Find the equation of the line parallel to the line 3x + 4y + 2 = 0 and passing through the point (–2, 3).
correct_answer: Since parallel lines share the same normal vector, the required line has the form 3x + 4y + d = 0. Substituting the point (–2, 3) gives 3(–2) + 4(3) + d = 0 ⇒ –6 + 12 + d = 0, so d = –6. Thus, the equation is 3x + 4y – 6 = 0.
explanation:
• Parallel lines have identical coefficients for x and y. Thus, the line parallel to 3x + 4y + 2 = 0 can be written as 3x + 4y + d = 0.
• Substitute (–2, 3) into the equation: 3(–2) + 4(3) + d = 0, which simplifies to –6 + 12 + d = 0, so d = –6.
• The final equation is 3x + 4y – 6 = 0.
topic: Parallel Lines; Equation of a Line

question_text: Find the equation of the line perpendicular to the line x + 7y + 5 = 0 and having x-intercept 3.
correct_answer: The slope of the given line x + 7y + 5 = 0 is obtained by writing it in slope-intercept form: 7y = −x − 5, y = −(1/7)x − 5/7, so its slope is −1/7. The slope of a line perpendicular to this is 7. With an x-intercept of 3, the line passes through (3, 0). Thus, its equation in point-slope form is: y − 0 = 7(x − 3), or y = 7x − 21.
explanation:
• Convert x + 7y + 5 = 0 to slope-intercept form: y = −(1/7)x − 5/7, giving a slope of −1/7.
• The perpendicular line must have slope equal to the negative reciprocal, which is 7.
• Since the line has an x-intercept of 3, it contains the point (3, 0). Use the point-slope form: y − 0 = 7(x − 3), resulting in y = 7x − 21.
topic: Perpendicular Lines; Equation of a Line

question_text: Find the angles between the lines √3x + y = 1 and x + √3y = 1.
correct_answer: Rewrite both equations in slope-intercept form. The first: y = −√3 x + 1, so slope m₁ = −√3. The second: √3y = −x + 1, hence y = −(1/√3)x + 1/√3, so slope m₂ = −1/√3. The angle between two lines is given by tanθ = |(m₁ − m₂)/(1 + m₁m₂)|. Here, tanθ = |(−√3 + 1/√3)/(1 + (−√3)(−1/√3)| = |(−(3 − 1)/√3)/(1 + 1)| = (2/√3)/2 = 1/√3, so θ = 30°.
explanation:
• For the line √3x + y = 1, solve for y to obtain y = −√3 x + 1 (slope m₁ = −√3).
• For the line x + √3y = 1, solve for y: √3y = −x + 1, so y = −(1/√3)x + 1/√3 (slope m₂ = −1/√3).
• The formula for the angle between two lines is tan θ = |(m₁ − m₂)/(1 + m₁m₂)|.
• Substitute the slopes: tan θ = |(−√3 + 1/√3)/(1 + (√3×1/√3)| = |(−(3−1)/√3)/2| = (2/√3)/2 = 1/√3.
• Since tan 30° = 1/√3, the angle between the lines is 30°.

question_text: The line through the points (h, 3) and (4, 1) intersects the line 7x + 9y − 19 = 0 at right angle. Find the value of h.
correct_answer:
The slope of the line through (h, 3) and (4, 1) is m = (1 − 3)/(4 − h) = −2/(4 − h). The given line 7x + 9y − 19 = 0 can be written in slope-intercept form as 9y = −7x + 19, so its slope is −7/9. For the lines to be perpendicular, the product of their slopes must be −1:
(−2/(4 − h)) × (−7/9) = 14/(9(4 − h)) = −1.
Solving, 14 = −9(4 − h) so 14 = −36 + 9h, hence 9h = 50, and h = 50/9.
explanation:
• Compute the slope of the line through (h, 3) and (4, 1): m = (1 − 3)/(4 − h) = −2/(4 − h).
• Rewrite 7x + 9y − 19 = 0 in slope-intercept form to get the slope m₁ = −7/9.
• For perpendicular lines, m × m₁ = −1. Hence, (−2/(4 − h)) × (−7/9) = 14/(9(4 − h)) should equal −1.
• Setting up the equation: 14/(9(4 − h)) = −1 leads to 14 = −9(4 − h).
• Solving: 14 = −36 + 9h, which gives 9h = 50 and h = 50/9.

question_text: Prove that the line through the point (x₁, y₁) and parallel to the line Ax + By + C = 0 is given by A(x − x₁) + B(y − y₁) = 0.
correct_answer: Any line parallel to Ax + By + C = 0 has the same normal vector (A, B), so it can be represented in the form A(x) + B(y) + D = 0. Since it passes through (x₁, y₁), substituting these coordinates gives A(x₁) + B(y₁) + D = 0, which implies D = −[A(x₁) + B(y₁)]. Therefore, the equation becomes A(x) + B(y) − [A(x₁) + B(y₁)] = 0, or equivalently, A(x − x₁) + B(y − y₁) = 0.
explanation:
• Parallel lines share the same direction ratios for their normal vectors. Because the given line has a normal vector (A, B), any line parallel to it must also have (A, B) as its normal vector.
• Thus, the general form of the parallel line is A(x) + B(y) + D = 0.
• Since the line passes through (x₁, y₁), substitute these values to get A(x₁) + B(y₁) + D = 0, hence D = −[A(x₁) + B(y₁)].
• Substituting back into the line equation yields A(x) + B(y) − [A(x₁) + B(y₁)] = 0, which can be factored as A(x − x₁) + B(y − y₁) = 0, thereby proving the required result.

question_text: Two lines passing through the point (2, 3) intersect each other at an angle of 60°. If the slope of one line is 2, find the equation of the other line.
correct_answer:
Let the slope of the other line be m. The angle between two lines with slopes m₁ and m₂ is given by tanθ = |(m₁ − m₂)/(1 + m₁m₂)|. Here m₁ = 2 and θ = 60° (tan60° = √3). Thus, |(2 − m)/(1 + 2m)| = √3. This produces two cases:
Case 1: (2 − m)/(1 + 2m) = √3  → 2 − m = √3(1 + 2m) → 2 − m = √3 + 2√3 m → (−m − 2√3 m) = √3 − 2, so m = (2 − √3)/(1 + 2√3).
Case 2: (2 − m)/(1 + 2m) = −√3 → 2 − m = −√3(1 + 2m) → 2 − m = −√3 − 2√3 m → Solving gives m = (2 + √3)/(1 − 2√3).
Thus, the equation of the other line is y − 3 = m(x − 2) with m taking either value.
explanation:
• For two lines with slopes m₁ and m₂, the angle between them is given by tanθ = |(m₁ − m₂)/(1 + m₁m₂)|.
• Here, m₁ = 2 and tan60° = √3, so |(2 − m)/(1 + 2m)| = √3.
• Setting up the equation leads to two cases: either (2 − m)/(1 + 2m) = √3 or (2 − m)/(1 + 2m) = −√3.
• Solve each case for m to obtain the two possible slopes for the second line.
• Finally, using the point (2, 3), the line is expressed in point-slope form: y − 3 = m(x − 2).

question_text: Find the equation of the right bisector of the line segment joining the points (3, 4) and (–1, 2).
correct_answer: First, find the midpoint of the segment joining (3, 4) and (–1, 2): M = ((3 + (–1))/2, (4 + 2)/2) = (1, 3). The slope of the segment is (2 − 4)/(–1 − 3) = (–2)/(–4) = 1/2. The slope of the perpendicular bisector is the negative reciprocal, −2. Thus, using the point-slope form, the equation is: y − 3 = −2(x − 1), or y = −2x + 5.
explanation:
• The midpoint M of the segment joining (3, 4) and (–1, 2) is calculated as: M = ((3 + (–1))/2, (4 + 2)/2) = (1, 3).
• The slope of the line through (3, 4) and (–1, 2) is m = (2 − 4)/(–1 − 3) = 1/2.
• The right (perpendicular) bisector will have a slope that is the negative reciprocal of 1/2, which is −2.
• Finally, the equation of the line passing through M with slope −2 is: y − 3 = −2(x − 1), which simplifies to y = −2x + 5.

question_text: Find the coordinates of the foot of the perpendicular from the point (–1, 3) to the line 3x – 4y – 16 = 0.
correct_answer:
For a line Ax + By + C = 0 and a point (x₀, y₀), the foot of the perpendicular (x', y') is given by:
 x' = x₀ − A(Ax₀ + By₀ + C)/(A² + B²) and y' = y₀ − B(Ax₀ + By₀ + C)/(A² + B²). 
Here, A = 3, B = −4, C = −16, and (x₀, y₀) = (–1, 3). Compute Ax₀ + By₀ + C = 3(–1) + (–4)(3) − 16 = –3 – 12 − 16 = –31. Also, A² + B² = 9 + 16 = 25.
Thus, x' = –1 − (3×(–31))/25 = –1 + 93/25 = (–25 + 93)/25 = 68/25, and y' = 3 − ((–4)×(–31))/25 = 3 − 124/25 = (75 − 124)/25 = –49/25.
So the foot of the perpendicular is (68/25, –49/25).
explanation:
• Use the formula for the foot of the perpendicular from a point (x₀, y₀) onto the line Ax + By + C = 0:
  x' = x₀ − (A*(Ax₀ + By₀ + C))/(A²+B²),  y' = y₀ − (B*(Ax₀ + By₀ + C))/(A²+B²).
• Here, substitute A = 3, B = −4, C = −16, and (x₀, y₀) = (–1, 3).
• First, calculate the expression Ax₀ + By₀ + C = −3 − 12 − 16 = −31 and A²+B² = 25.
• Then compute x' = –1 + (93/25) = 68/25 and y' = 3 − (124/25) = –49/25.
• Therefore, the foot of the perpendicular is (68/25, –49/25).
topic: Perpendicular from a Point to a Line

question_text: The perpendicular from the origin to the line y = mx + c meets it at the point (–1, 2). Find the values of m and c.
correct_answer: Since the foot of the perpendicular from the origin to the line y = mx + c is (–1, 2), two conditions hold. First, (–1, 2) lies on the line, so 2 = m(–1) + c, which gives c = 2 + m. Second, the line joining the origin (0, 0) to (–1, 2) has slope 2/–1 = –2. Since this line is perpendicular to y = mx + c, whose slope is m, we must have m × (–2) = –1, so m = 1/2. Then c = 2 + 1/2 = 5/2.
explanation:
• The given point (–1, 2) satisfies the line: 2 = m(–1) + c, hence c = 2 + m.
• The line joining (0, 0) (the origin) and (–1, 2) has slope (2 − 0)/(–1 − 0) = –2.
• Since the foot of the perpendicular implies that this line is perpendicular to y = mx + c, then m must be the negative reciprocal of –2, that is, m = 1/2.
• Substitute m = 1/2 into c = 2 + m to get c = 2 + 1/2 = 5/2.
topic: Perpendicular from a Point to a Line; Slope Relationships

question_text: If p and q are the lengths of the perpendiculars from the origin to the lines x cos θ − y sin θ = k cos 2θ and x sec θ + y cosec θ = k, respectively, prove that p² + 4q² = k².
correct_answer: For the first line, the distance from the origin is given by |0 − k cos2θ|/√(cos²θ + sin²θ) = |k cos2θ|. Hence, p = k|cos2θ|. For the second line, write it in the standard form. Its distance from the origin is |k|/√(sec²θ + cosec²θ). Since sec²θ + cosec²θ = 1/cos²θ + 1/sin²θ = (sin²θ + cos²θ)/(sin²θ cos²θ) = 1/(sin²θ cos²θ), we have √(sec²θ + cosec²θ) = 1/(|sinθ cosθ|) = 2/|sin2θ|. Thus, q = |k|/(2/|sin2θ|) = k|sin2θ|/2. Then, p² + 4q² = k² cos²2θ + 4(k² sin²2θ/4) = k²(cos²2θ + sin²2θ) = k², proving the stated result.
explanation:
• For the line x cosθ − y sinθ = k cos2θ, the perpendicular distance from (0, 0) is |−k cos2θ| divided by √(cos²θ + sin²θ) which equals k|cos2θ|, so p = k|cos2θ|.
• For the second line, x secθ + y cosecθ = k, rewrite the coefficients so that the distance formula applies. The normalizing factor is √(sec²θ + cosec²θ). Recognize that sec²θ + cosec²θ = 1/cos²θ + 1/sin²θ = 1/(sin²θ cos²θ) = 4/sin²2θ, hence the denominator becomes 2/|sin2θ|. Thus, q = k|sin2θ|/2.
• Squaring, p² = k² cos²2θ and 4q² = 4*(k² sin²2θ/4) = k² sin²2θ. Adding gives k²(cos²2θ + sin²2θ) = k², since cos²θ + sin²θ = 1.
• This completes the proof.

question_text: In the triangle ABC with vertices A (2, 3), B (4, –1) and C (1, 2), find the equation and length of the altitude from the vertex A.
correct_answer: First, find the equation of the side BC. The slope of BC, through B (4, –1) and C (1, 2), is m = (2 – (–1))/(1 – 4) = 3/(–3) = −1. The line BC can be written as: using point B, y + 1 = −1(x − 4), i.e., y = −x + 3. The altitude from A (2, 3) is perpendicular to BC so its slope is the negative reciprocal of −1, which is 1. Using point-slope form, the altitude is: y − 3 = 1(x − 2), or y = x + 1. The length of the altitude is the distance from A (2, 3) to the line BC: distance = |(1)(2) + (1)(3) − 3|/√(1² + 1²) = |2 + 3 − 3|/√2 = 2/√2 = √2.
explanation:
• Determine the slope of side BC using B (4, –1) and C (1, 2): m = (2 – (–1))/(1 − 4) = 3/(−3) = −1. Its equation, using point B, is y + 1 = −1(x − 4) ⇒ y = −x + 3.
• The altitude from A must be perpendicular to BC. The slope of a line perpendicular to a line with slope −1 is 1.
• The equation of the altitude through A (2, 3) is then y − 3 = 1(x − 2), hence y = x + 1.
• To get the length, use the distance from point A to the line BC. Writing BC as x + y − 3 = 0, the distance is |2 + 3 − 3|/√(1²+1²) = 2/√2 = √2.
topic: Altitude in a Triangle; Distance from a Point to a Line

question_text: If p is the length of the perpendicular from the origin to the line whose intercepts on the axes are a and b, then show that (1/a²) + (1/b²) = (1/p²).
correct_answer: A line with intercepts a and b can be written in the form x/a + y/b = 1. Its standard form is bx + ay − ab = 0. The distance from the origin (0, 0) to this line is p = |−ab|/√(a² + b²) = ab/√(a² + b²) (taking positive value for length). Then p² = a²b²/(a² + b²). Taking reciprocals, 1/p² = (a² + b²)/(a²b²) = 1/a² + 1/b², which is the desired result.
explanation:
• A line intercepting the axes at a and b is given by x/a + y/b = 1. Multiply through by ab to obtain bx + ay − ab = 0.
• The distance from the origin to the line Ax + By + C = 0 is given by |C|/√(A²+B²). Here, A = b, B = a, and C = −ab. Thus, p = ab/√(a²+b²).
• Squaring gives p² = a²b²/(a²+b²). Taking the reciprocal yields 1/p² = (a²+b²)/(a²b²) = 1/a² + 1/b².
• This completes the proof.
